channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Pounds Civilian Targets as War Enters 4th Week
item.description: Rescue workers began pulling some survivors from the wreckage of a theater in Mariupol where hundreds, including children, were believed to be sheltering. Ukrainian air defenses claimed to shoot down Russian planes and missiles over Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladimir Golinkov, 55, collected magazines from the remnants of his home, after pieces of a Russian cruise missile fell onto a high-rise building in east Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Who Killed Three Aid Workers for Doctors Without Borders in Ethiopia?
item.description: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: As Russia Digs In, What’s the Risk of Nuclear War? ‘It’s Not Zero.’
item.description: A series of shifts in Russian statements about using nuclear weapons has led some analysts to believe that the Kremlin sees a nuclear exchange as a viable strategy.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: A Russian army RS-24 Yars ballistic missile system moving through Red Square during a military parade, in Moscow, in 2020.

item.title: It Seemed Like a Big Potato. Then Guinness Weighed In.
item.description: A couple in New Zealand found a giant growth in their garden, named it Doug and applied to the Guinness Book of World Records. Then the results of a DNA analysis came in.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Doug, as bronze and burly as any Thanksgiving turkey, in Donna and Colin Craig-Browns’s garden near Hamilton, New Zealand, in November.

item.title: Oxxxymiron, Russian Rapper, Brings a Banned Antiwar Message to Istanbul
item.description: The rapper, Oxxxymiron, said proceeds from his show would go to help Ukrainian refugees. Russians at the concert denounced the war but said they felt helpless to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I hate feeling so powerless,” Oxxxymiron, one of Russia’s most popular rappers, said at a benefit concert for Ukrainian refugees at an Istanbul club on Tuesday.

item.title: Mass Graves in Syria Could Hold Evidence of War Crimes
item.description: Two sites have been located, believed to hold thousands of bodies of Syrians killed in detention centers administered by President Bashar al-Assad’s government during the civil war.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Tsunami Alert Canceled After Big Quake Near Fukushima
item.description: Two small tsunami waves hit the coast after the 7.3 earthquake. Millions were without power. Three hours after the quake there were no reports of casualties and the extent of the damage was unclear.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, which was seriously damaged by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, earlier this month.

item.title: In Cambodia, Khmer Rouge Horrors Few Want to Remember
item.description: Two-thirds of Cambodians are under the age of 30 — born decades after the Khmer Rouge’s totalitarian terror and the American carpet-bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Nadia Shira Cohen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The waterfront along the Mekong River in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in January. Much of the population has no personal memory of the country’s deadliest years.

item.title: Oligarchs Got Richer Despite Sanctions. Will This Time Be Different?
item.description: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo and Jane Bradley
item.media:description: Arkady Rotenberg, a Russian billionaire, has stayed wealthy and spent lavishly despite sanctions against him.

item.title: After Six-Year Ordeal in Iran, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Is Freed
item.description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a charity worker, was arrested and detained in Tehran in 2016. She was released along with another dual citizen of Iran and the U.K. after the resolution of a longstanding British debt.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, shown in a photograph provided by her family, was initially charged with plotting to overthrow the Iranian government.

item.title: Impunity for Syria War Crimes Casts Shadow Over Ukraine
item.description: Syria, with Russian support, used many of the brutal tactics now seen in Ukraine — and its dictator stayed in power. That conflict offers lessons for Russia’s leader, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homs, Syria, in 2014. The Syrian war began 11 years ago this month with an anti-Assad uprising that spiraled into a multisided conflict.

item.title: Honduras Judge Approves Extradition of Ex-President to U.S.
item.description: Former President Juan Orlando Hernández is facing drug-trafficking and weapons charges
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Former President Juan Orlando Hernández in shackles at the headquarters of the national police in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, in February.

item.title: In South Korea, a Spike in Covid Cases Meets a Collective Shrug
item.description: A country that once had one of the world’s most aggressive coronavirus policies is opting to learn to live with the virus, even in the face of a soaring infection rate.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and John Yoon
item.media:description: A crowded street in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, when the country set a daily record for coronavirus infections: 621,328.

item.title: Amid Russia Invasion, I.R.S. Aims to Police Oligarch Sanctions
item.description: It wants to add agents to a 3,000-person investigations unit to help crack down on attempts by Russian oligarchs to evade sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Charles Rettig, the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, is asking Congress for more resources to expand its role in investigating attempts to evade U.S. sanctions on Russia.

item.title: A City Under Siege
item.description: We give you a rare dispatch from Mariupol, Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Dead bodies are put into a mass grave on the outskirts of Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: UNESCO Will Send Body Armor to Ukrainian Journalists
item.description: The U.N. agency said thousands of Ukrainian journalists with no protective equipment or training were now covering the war. At least four journalists have been killed.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Pierre Zakrzewski, a Fox News cameraman, left, and Oleksandra Kuvshynova, a Ukrainian journalist, center right, were killed outside Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: In Some Parts of the World, the War in Ukraine Seems Justified
item.description: In countries friendly toward Russia, people are troubled by the war and loss of life, but some say they think that Putin has a point.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A woman reads a Vietnamese newspaper featuring front-page coverage of the Russian invasion of Ukraine at her stall in Hanoi last month.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: More U.S. military aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukranian soldier in the strategic port city of Odessa.

item.title: U.S. Adds ‘Kamikaze Drones’ as More Weapons Flow to Ukraine
item.description: NATO allies are focused on providing Kyiv with high-tech defensive weapons that are easy to use and move.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters training in early March to use a British-provided NLAW antitank weapon.

item.title: Biden Calls Putin ‘War Criminal’ in Verbal Escalation With Russia
item.description: The U.S. president’s unscripted remarks echoed comments other American officials have made recently.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Aid, Invoking America’s Darkest Days
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Powerful Quake Off Japan Rekindles Fears of Another Fukushima
item.description: Tsunami warnings in a region hit by nuclear disaster in 2011 were lifted after a few hours. The damage was still being assessed, but it appeared contained.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, which was seriously damaged by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, earlier this month. Nuclear power plants were under inspection early Thursday.

item.title: As Russian Troop Deaths Climb, Morale May Be an Issue
item.description: More than 7,000 Russian troops have been killed in less than three weeks of fighting, according to conservative U.S. estimates.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier used an antitank weapon to destroy a Russian vehicle in Irpin, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Spain Seizes Another Russian Yacht Believed to Belong to an Oligarch
item.description: The ship was impounded in the Spanish port of Tarragona pending an inspection to establish its exact ownership, Spain’s transport ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder and Michael Forsythe
item.media:description: A security guard stood at the dock where the Crescent, a megayacht, was docked in Tarragona, Spain. The Crescent was impounded by the Spanish government on Wednesday.

item.title: Transcript: Zelensky’s Speech to Congress
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed a joint meeting of the House and Senate to press his case for more aid to Ukraine amid devastating attacks by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran’s Attack Was Response to Secret Israeli Attack on Drone Site
item.description: Israel and Iran are pushing the boundaries of a long-running clandestine war that is increasingly spilling out of the shadows.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Iranian missiles struck this building in Erbil, Iraq, on Sunday that Iran said housed an Israeli intelligence operation.

item.title: W.H.O. Delays Assessing Russia’s Sputnik Vaccine Over Ukraine War
item.description: An official with the World Health Organization said “the assessment, along with inspections, have been affected.”
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Gamaleya Research Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses administering doses of Covid-19 vaccines in Moscow in July.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Zelensky Speaks to Congress
item.description: Plus an offshore earthquake in Japan and mass graves in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivers a virtual address to Congress in the U.S. Capitol Visitors Center Congressional Auditorium in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Justin Smith, Former Bloomberg C.E.O., Offers New Details on Media Start-up
item.description: The former Bloomberg Media C.E.O. offered new details on the venture he is starting with the journalist Ben Smith.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Justin Smith in 2014. The new publication, its co-founder said, “is very intentionally going to be able to live in Asia or Europe or the Middle East or America.”

item.title: Putin Assails Russians Who Back the West, Signaling More Repression
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia denigrated European and American leaders, and Russians who disagreed with him. Analysts fear his remarks could signal a new wave of repression.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An antiwar protester being carried away by Russian police officers during a demonstration in Moscow last month.

item.title: Saharan Sands Float North to Europe, Coating Cities With Dust
item.description: A European monitoring service projected that the dust, which cast an eerie orange pall over much of the continent, could reach as far as Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Vast stretches of Spain, including the Almeria fortress, were cloaked in orange as airborne dust particles wafted up from the Sahara.

item.title: Olga Smirnova, Opposed to the Ukraine War, Quits the Bolshoi
item.description: Olga Smirnova said she was against the war in Ukraine “with all the fibers of my soul.” Now, she has joined the Dutch National Ballet.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ekaterina Shtukina/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Olga Smirnova, with Artemy Belyakov, in George Balanchine’s “Diamonds” at the Bolshoi in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Exports to Russia Blocked by U.S. and Its Allies
item.description: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The Yangshan Deep Water Port in Shanghai. Chinese officials have hinted that they will comply with export controls put in place by the United States to keep advanced technology from Russia.

item.title: Boris Johnson Travels to Saudi Arabia for Oil Diplomacy
item.description: At home, critics had another take on Mr. Johnson’s efforts to reduce western reliance on Russian energy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, center, with Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, right, on Wednesday in Riyadh.

item.title: Benjamin Hall, Fox News Journalist Who Was Injured in Ukraine, Is Now Safe
item.description: Benjamin Hall was seriously injured in an incident that killed a Fox News cameraman and a young Ukrainian journalist.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Putin’s War on Ukraine Is About Ethnicity and Empire
item.description: Biden’s framework of ‘democracies versus autocracies’ misses the darker source of this war, which has deep roots in Russian history and thought.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Billboards quoting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Simferopol, Crimea, this month. Left to right, they say: “The real power is in justice and truth, which is on our side”; “Russia doesn't start wars, Russia ends them”; and “We want the demilitarization and denazification of Ukraine.”

item.title: Imagining Peace in Ukraine
item.description: Is it possible? And what could it look like?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: People board an evacuation train in Odessa, Ukraine yesterday.

item.title: Ukraine Seeks Tougher Sanctions at Russian Ports
item.description: A top Ukrainian official criticized companies in the United States and Greece for helping Russia continue to profit from oil despite its attack on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The Novorossiysk oil terminal on the Black Sea in 2018. Data showed that a tanker leased by Chevron and carrying crude left for the Netherlands on Friday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A clandestine visit by European leaders to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews evacuated civilians from a residential building on Tuesday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Zelensky Urges More Leaders to Visit Kyiv After Visit by 3 NATO Leaders
item.description: The leaders from Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia “fear nothing,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said, and he urged other leaders to make similar visits.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: A handout photograph from the Ukrainian government of President Volodymyr Zelensky with leaders from Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: North Korea’s Projectile Launch Fails, South Korea Says
item.description: The projectile, fired from outside Pyongyang, failed “immediately after liftoff,” the South Korean military said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A TV broadcast in March at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, showed a file image of a North Korean missile launch.

item.title: In Reversal, Guatemala Shelves Anti-Abortion Law
item.description: President Alejandro Giammattei said he would veto the bill days after his allies pushed it through the legislature, a move that surprised analysts, human rights activists and officials.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: A demonstration last week in Guatemala City against a bill that would bolster the prison sentence for women who obtain abortions and ban same-sex marriages.

item.title: Russian Bombardment of Kyiv Continues While European Leaders Visit
item.description: The prime ministers of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia made the trip as a show of solidarity, but it also bared divisions with other European Union members.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews evacuating civilians from a residential building that was struck by shelling on Tuesday in Kyiv.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: E.U. Leaders Visit Kyiv
item.description: Plus the ripple effects of China’s surge of Covid cases and a once-perilous road in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews evacuated civilians from a residential building that was hit in the western part of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Mounting Data Shows J&J Vaccine as Effective as Pfizer and Moderna
item.description: Once dismissed as less effective, the vaccine now seems to be preventing infections and illness about as well as the two mRNA options.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Johnson & Johnson vaccinations in Soweto, South Africa, last year.

item.title: 3 European Leaders Say They Are in Kyiv to Support Ukraine
item.description: “It is here, in war-torn Kyiv, that history is being made,” one European leader wrote after arriving in Ukraine’s battered capital.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Explosions hit central Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: Russian War Protester Who Burst Onto State TV Is Fined
item.description: In a video following her sentence, the state TV worker said she had been interrogated for 14 hours and “spent two days without sleep.” She still faces a lengthy prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Marina Ovsyannikova outside court in Moscow.

item.title: Ukraine War Shifts the Agenda in Congress, Empowering the Center
item.description: With a crisis rocking Europe, the left is shelving demands for defense cuts and a swift end to fossil fuels, while on the right, Trump-era foreign policy and criticism of Ukraine are fading.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will deliver a virtual address to Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: How Shackleton’s Endurance Was Found
item.description: “Gents, I want to introduce you to the Endurance.” More than a century after sinking in Antarctic waters, the legendary ship was found with just days to spare.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The helm of Endurance, seen for the first time in more than 100 years on March 5.

item.title: Biden Will Travel to Europe Next Week for NATO Meeting
item.description: The president will travel to Brussels for the NATO session, and will also attend a European Union summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden plans to travel to Europe next week for meetings with NATO and European Union leaders.

item.title: Russian Artists Lose the Tools of Their Trades as Companies Pull Out
item.description: Creative professionals have been cut off from Western clients and from the products and services they use to make, market and get paid for their work.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Alexander, a Russian photographer who did not want to give his last name out of safety concerns, fled Moscow for Tbilisi, Georgia, and is documenting the nearly 1,250-mile journey.

item.title: Officials in Mariupol Struggle to Account for the Dead
item.description: The coastal city, a battleground for weeks, is under an increasingly relentless Russian assault that is taking an unspeakable toll.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A church damaged by shelling in a residential area of Mariupol last week.

item.title: Ukraine’s National Anthem Reverberates Around the World
item.description: “Ukraine’s glory hasn’t perished,” begins the anthem, which is being played by orchestras worldwide as a sign of solidarity with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Sergei Belski/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
